FIND YOUR DEALBREAKERS  

Executives often struggle to identify their boundaries.  

They know they have boundaries, but can't express them.  

If you can't articulate them, others may not respect them.  

Think of someone who pulls you off your essential path.  

Make a list of your dealbreakers.  

These are requests or activities you refuse unless they align with your priorities.  

Another way to find dealbreakers is to note violations.  

Write down any time you feel violated by someone's request.  

It doesn't have to be extreme to notice it.  

Even a small "pinch" can indicate a minor boundary violation.  

A twinge of resentment can reveal hidden boundaries.  

Unwanted invitations or small favors can be clues.  

CRAFT SOCIAL CONTRACTS  

I once worked with a colleague who had a different approach.  

People predicted conflicts between us.  

However, our relationship was harmonious.  

I laid out my priorities at the start.  

I explained what extra work I would and wouldn't take on.  

I suggested we agree on our goals.  

I shared what mattered to me.  

I asked him to share his priorities too.  

We created a "social contract."  

This helped us avoid wasting time.  

We avoided burdensome requests and distractions.  

As a result, we could contribute at our highest level.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Identifying and articulating personal boundaries, or dealbreakers, is essential for maintaining focus on one's priorities and achieving effective collaboration.
